title: 107_hr5526
content: The "Stealth Lobbyist Disclosure Act of 2002" requires certain coalitions and associations to disclose their lobbying activities. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 defines a client as any person or entity that hires someone for compensation to conduct lobbying activities on their behalf. This includes coalitions and associations that employ lobbyists. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 defines a client as any person or entity that hires someone for compensation to conduct lobbying activities on their behalf. When a coalition or association retains individuals to conduct lobbying activities, each individual member is considered the client. However, certain tax-exempt associations are treated as the client themselves. Certain tax-exempt associations are treated as the client themselves, rather than individual members, when engaging in lobbying activities. Certain tax-exempt associations are treated as the client themselves, rather than individual members, when engaging in lobbying activities. Members of a coalition or association contributing less than $1,000 per semiannual period towards influencing legislation are not required to be included in registration under section 4. Certain tax-exempt associations are treated as the client themselves when engaging in lobbying activities. Contributions exceeding $1,000 in a semiannual period mark the date of first employment for lobbying contacts. Look-thru rules apply to coalitions or associations treated as clients. The amendments made by this section apply to coalitions and associations listed on registration statements filed under the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 after a certain date. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 requires coalitions and associations to file new registration statements within 30 days of the enactment of this Act for any lobbying contacts made after that date.
